lib/hashlittle.c File Reference

contains a hash function used to hash a chunk of data and return a hash number that can be used to identify the data. More...

Functions

uint32_t hashlittle (const void *key, size_t length, uint32_t initval)
 hash the data and return an hash number.

Detailed Description

contains a hash function used to hash a chunk of data and return a hash number that can be used to identify the data.

Apply with care to double floating numbers because of round off error.

Function Documentation

uint32_t hashlittle ( const void *  key,
size_t  length,
uint32_t  initval 
)

hash the data and return an hash number.

Returns:
a hash number
Parameters:
[in] key The data
[in] length The length of the data in byte
[in] initval The initial hash number 
00082 {
00083   
00084   uint32_t a,b,c;                                          /* internal state */
00085   size_t dstep=(length/10000);/*jump */
00086   dstep=dstep<1?1:dstep;
00087 
00088   size_t dstep12=dstep*12;
00089   size_t dstep3=dstep*3;
00090 
00091   /* Set up the internal state */
00092   a = b = c = 0xdeadbeef + ((uint32_t)length) + initval;
00093 
00094 
00095   const uint32_t *k = (const uint32_t *)key;         /* read 32-bit chunks */
00096 
00097   /*------ all but last block: aligned reads and affect 32 bits of (a,b,c) */
00098   while (length > dstep12)
00099     {
00100       a += k[0];
00101       b += k[1];
00102       c += k[2];
00103       mix(a,b,c);
00104       length -= dstep12;
00105       k += dstep3;
00106     }
00107 
00108   /*----------------------------- handle the last (probably partial) block */
00109   /* 
00110    * "k[2]&0xffffff" actually reads beyond the end of the string, but
00111    * then masks off the part it's not allowed to read.  Because the
00112    * string is aligned, the masked-off tail is in the same word as the
00113    * rest of the string.  Every machine with memory protection I've seen
00114    * does it on word boundaries, so is OK with this.  But VALGRIND will
00115    * still catch it and complain.  The masking trick does make the hash
00116    * noticably faster for short strings (like English words).
00117    */
00118 #ifndef VALGRIND
00119 
00120   switch(length)
00121     {
00122     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00123     case 11: c+=k[2]&0xffffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00124     case 10: c+=k[2]&0xffff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00125     case 9 : c+=k[2]&0xff; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00126     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00127     case 7 : b+=k[1]&0xffffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00128     case 6 : b+=k[1]&0xffff; a+=k[0]; break;
00129     case 5 : b+=k[1]&0xff; a+=k[0]; break;
00130     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00131     case 3 : a+=k[0]&0xffffff; break;
00132     case 2 : a+=k[0]&0xffff; break;
00133     case 1 : a+=k[0]&0xff; break;
00134     case 0 : return c;              /* zero length strings require no mixing */
00135     }
00136 
00137 #else /* make valgrind happy */
00138   {
00139   const uint8_t  *k8;
00140   k8 = (const uint8_t *)k;
00141   switch(length)
00142     {
00143     case 12: c+=k[2]; b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00144     case 11: c+=((uint32_t)k8[10])<<16;  /* fall through */
00145     case 10: c+=((uint32_t)k8[9])<<8;    /* fall through */
00146     case 9 : c+=k8[8];                   /* fall through */
00147     case 8 : b+=k[1]; a+=k[0]; break;
00148     case 7 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[6])<<16;   /* fall through */
00149     case 6 : b+=((uint32_t)k8[5])<<8;    /* fall through */
00150     case 5 : b+=k8[4];                   /* fall through */
00151     case 4 : a+=k[0]; break;
00152     case 3 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[2])<<16;   /* fall through */
00153     case 2 : a+=((uint32_t)k8[1])<<8;    /* fall through */
00154     case 1 : a+=k8[0]; break;
00155     case 0 : return c;
00156     }
00157   }
00158 #endif /* !valgrind */
00159   final(a,b,c);
00160   return c;
00161 }
